Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the KMD model of defi will be toward the low cost of the spectrum. other than the lost rewards from locking the KMD and the 0.0001 txfees, there wont be much costs. for the cost of txfees and not collecting rewards, you can get an interest free loan of up to 80%. you can prevent it from being liquidated by adding more funds if it gets close to 90% threshold. it could be that as the price of KMD drops and peoples positions get closer to being liquidated, it will create a demand for KMD to be purchased so it wont be liquidated

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if this liquidation prevention demand can be 50%+ of the liquidation sell pressure, that would actually create a net demand. when the price of KMD is going up, the simple fact that people can issue more stablecoins should create the demand

Author: Privatoshi#9487
Content: I'm curious. What makes a stablecoin lose its $1 stability?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in the event there is a sudden and rapid loss of value that isnt recovered and there is no arbitrage profits to be made

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in this case, the loss in the peg will be socialized across all issues evenly, based on the value of the KMD that backs the issued stablecoins (for that specific chain)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as the trading value of the pegged and not fully backed coin reduces, the arbitrage profits will reappear

Author: Privatoshi#9487
Content: And it will rebalance

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, it will automatically rebalance, though it could be trading at a discount for a while, depending on the exact pricing level.

Author: Privatoshi#9487
Content: Fall down to 93-99 cents

Author: Privatoshi#9487
Content: Then back to $1

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: considering we have stable coins that are backed by some murky centralized issuers, a blockchain backed pegged coin will be fully transparent as to how much KMD is backing it

Author: Privatoshi#9487
Content: That's key

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is impossible to predict the levels in the case of a breakdown in the peg, which might never even happen.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it seems that tether is fractionally backed, yet it still maintains its peg, so maybe if the backing falls below 110%, the USDK peg will hold also.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as the price falls, the liquidation is constantly improving the overall system balance, so a gradual decline of even 90% will still maintain the peg

Author: Privatoshi#9487
Content:
How do you know all of this?
The financial aspect of it

Author: Privatoshi#9487
Content: It's a good thing for KMD

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is only the sudden and very large and relatively long term drop that will cause the backing to fail, which could cause the peg to drop below the $1. in which case, all holders of the stablecoin would proportionally absorb the shortfall, ultimately if what you use to back something goes down in value massively, it cant support the price of an external thing. even the bank of england couldnt maintain the pound. so the key is to have things degrade gracefully

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i know all of this as i thought through how it would work

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there isnt any strong incentive for anybody to sell KMD to drop its price as there are no ways to short its price currently. maybe that will change, but without a high volume shorting mechanism, it seems the price declines would be relatively gradual

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: of course in BTC terms the price can be very volatile, but that is more due to BTC, if to look at KMD price in terms of fiat, the drops are usually temporary or gradual. giving plenty of time for people to add more KMD to their account or liquidate, which keeps the peg in balance

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oh, people can also pay down part of what they borrowed to improve their equity, so that will also help restore the balance
